{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use British English|date=August 2015}} [[File:National Gallery London Sainsbury Wing 2006-04-17.jpg|right|thumb|The Sainsbury Wing at the National Gallery in London, location of the Micro Gallery.]]
A '''micro gallery''' was a computer-based guide to archives and museum collections, first developed for the collections at the [[National Gallery, London|National Gallery]] in London, UK<ref>[http://www.springerlink.com/content/67n7011802532244/ The micro gallery at the national gallery of London], ''[[Archives and Museum Informatics]]'', 6(2):5–10, [[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]], June 1992. {{DOI|10.1007/BF02770344}}</ref><ref>''[http://www.cogapp.com/home/micro-gallery.html Case Studies: Micro Gallery, National Gallery, London]'', Cogapp.</ref> It took three years to develop by the company [[Cognitive Applications]], and opened in July 1991 as part of the facilities in the [[Sainsbury Wing]]. Visitors could use the system to determine which pictures they would like to see in the gallery. It was possible to print out [[personalization|personalised]] information for use during the visit. The Micro Gallery ran for 14 years and a [[CD-ROM]] with similar facilities was produced.
In 1995, a similar facility was produced for the [[National Gallery of Art]] in Washington, D.C., USA.<ref>[http://doi.ieeecomputersociety.org/10.1109/MMUL.1998.10007 In the News], ''[[IEEE MultiMedia]]'', 5(2):9–13, April–June, 1998. {{DOI|10.1109/MMUL.1998.10007}}</ref><ref>''[http://www.nga.gov/press/1999/cdrompr.shtm The National Gallery of Art's Micro Gallery is now available on CD-ROM] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080531083129/http://www.nga.gov/press/1999/cdrompr.shtm |date=31 May 2008 }}'', National Gallery of Art, 24 March 1999.</ref>
== References ==
<references />
[[Category:1991 software]] [[Category:2005 disestablishments]] [[Category:Information technology projects]] [[Category:National Gallery, London]] [[Category:National Gallery of Art]]
{{technology-stub}}

{{unreferenced|date=March 2011}} {{Infobox Software |name = mobile PhoneTools |logo = |caption = |screenshot = |developer = Avanquest |latest_release_version = 5.17d |latest_release_date = {{Start date and age|2009|5|14}} |operating_system = [[Microsoft Windows]] |genre = [[Personal information manager]] |license = [[Commerce|Commercial]] |website = [http://www.avanquest.com/USA/index.html www.Avanquest.com] }} {{lowercase|title=mobile PhoneTools}} '''mobile PhoneTools''' is a program written by the French-based company Avanquest Software (formerly BVRP). The program allows users of [[Motorola]] and other brands of [[cellular phones]] to connect their cellular phones to their [[personal computer]].
mobile PhoneTools is distributed as an [[Original equipment manufacturer|OEM]] product with Motorola phones by some telcos. The Motorola edition of the software is called '''Motorola PhoneTools'''. mobile PhoneTools is sold online as a retail product as well. Another version of mobile PhoneTools, called '''Mobile Phone Suite''', is a special edition designed to work with the [[Intel]] [[Centrino]] dual-core chip.
mobile PhoneTools requires [[Bluetooth]], data cable, or [[IrDA]] connection to operate. The retail version can be purchased as a bundle with either a Bluetooth dongle or a data cable.
Following functionalities are included in the retail version of mobile PhoneTools: * Synchronizing of phonebook and calendar with [[personal information manager]] (e.g. [[Microsoft Outlook]]). * Connecting the computer to the Internet via cell phone's data service (e.g. [[GPRS]], [[Enhanced Data Rates for GSM Evolution|EDGE]]). * Reading and composing [[text message]]s or [[email]]s on the computer. * Transferring of sound, image, and video files between computer and cell phone. (does not support [[Java ME]] [[MIDlet]]s) * Updating cell phone [[firmware]].
[[Category:Personal information managers]] [[Category:PIM-software for Windows]]

'''mysqlBind/unxsBind''' is a [[DNS management software]] system. It supports [[Internet Systems Consortium|ISC]] [[BIND]] [[Domain Name System|DNS]] and is distributed as [[open source software]] under the [[GNU General Public License]].
mysqlBind/unxsBind has been in use since the late 1990s. It initially was designed to replace [[perl]]/[[bash (Unix shell)|bash]] based sets of maintenance scripts that made deployment and upkeep of large DNS systems time consuming and prone to human error.<ref>Gary Wallis, Website, April 2004, "[http://venus.openisp.net/openisp/unxsVZ/browser/trunk/unxsBind unxsBind]", May 2010</ref>
==Design== mysqlBind (now unxsBind) centralizes all data in a replicated [[SQL]] database and limits any DNS configuration errors to one [[Reliability engineering|software package failure point]]. unxsBind is a BIND9+ server management system only, not a DNS server, and generates DNS server specific configuration files so that the DNS server does not have to rely on a live SQL database. The unxsBind used SQL server is only needed to be operational for administration and deployment of new [[DNS zone|zone]]s, new [[resource record]]s, resource records changes and zone [[List of DNS record types#SOA|SOA]] changes. This non-reliance on a live SQL database has been a major point for reliable deployment of large scale DNS services.<ref>Dilva Garmendia, Website, May 2008, "[http://unixservice.com/?gcPage=Content&uContentType=1&uContent=21 unixservice.com]", May 2010</ref>
unxsBind is based on a "Company/Organization-Contact-Role" login and permissions model, such that end user organization contacts can manage their own DNS data from a shared infrastructure. This unxsBind shared infrastructure supports an unlimited number of organizations that can then administrate their own DNS resources, such as [[IP address|IP]] blocks, [[DNS zone|zone]]s and [[resource record]]s. unxsBind provides for the centralized management of multiple independent name servers across data center boundaries.
The unxsBind system consists of a back end (unxsBind/iDNS) interface, and several example end user interfaces: The idnsAdmin admin interface, and the end user idnsOrg and vdnsOrg interfaces. All provided interfaces run on SQL originated [[HTML]]/[[CSS]]/[[JavaScript]] templates organized in types and sets for on the fly interface "skin" changes and new interfaces. This along with the backend/DNS-configuration-engine and front-end interface model used in unxsBind is meant to provide the DNS service provider with a simple path to provision their own custom interfaces with advanced functionality. For example, a DNS service provider branded [[AJAX]] based interface with [[punycode]] hostname conversion for [[IDNA]] support.
Secondary and master zones, secondary-only zones, forward zones, hidden masters and hidden external master zones are all supported. Recent versions allow unlimited [[Split-horizon DNS|split horizon]] configurations (multiple BIND 9.3+ views). [[NAPTR]], [[AAAA record|AAAA]], and many other complex resource records are supported with input validation and contextual glossary based help. Wizards are provided for error prone complex DNS configuration management operations, e.g. in-addr.arpa reverse dns NS delegation using [[CIDR]] and $GENERATE directives. [[LDAP]] login support is provided for the vdnsOrg interface.
A [[CentOS]] 5.2+ [[Yellowdog Updater, Modified|yum]] installable version is available. Advanced features such as [[High availability|HA]] and LDAP single sign-on require that the system be configured and installed from source.
==See also== * [[DNS hosting service]] * [[Cluster manager]] * [[DNSSEC]] - Latest versions of mysqlBind/iDNS support BIND 9.6 for easy DNSSEC-bis implementation and operations management.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://venus.openisp.net/unxsVZ/browser/trunk/unxsBind mysqlBind (now unxsBind) ] - The home of mysqlBind/unxsBind * {{GitHub|unxs0/unxsBind}} * {{Openhub|id=p_d12012|name=mysqlBind}} * [http://mysql-bind.sourceforge.net/ MySQL BIND SDB Driver] at [[SourceForge]] * {{SourceForge|id=mysql-bind|name=MySQL BIND SDB Driver}} * {{Freecode|id=mysqlbind|name=mysqlBind}} * [http://www.dnssec-tools.org/ www.dnssec-tools.org] - Tools for checking DNSSEC-bis deployments * {{Dmoz|Computers/Software/Internet/Servers/Address_Management|Address Management}} - Listings of DNS software * {{Dmoz|Computers/Internet/Protocols/DNS/DNS_Providers|DNS Providers}} - Listings of providers of DNS services * {{Dmoz|Computers/Internet/Protocols/DNS/DNS_Providers/Dynamic_DNS|Dynamic DNS}} - Listings of providers of dynamic DNS services * [http://www.digitalnerds.net/featured/how-to-install-bind9-with-mysql/ How To Install Bind9+MySQL] - step by step how-to of bind9+mysqlbind driver on debian.
[[Category:Domain name system]]

{{distinguish|National Historical Museum (Brazil)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2018}} {{Infobox Museum |name = National Museum of Brazil |native_name = Museu Nacional |logo = Museu nacional logo.png |image = File:Palácio de São Cristóvão.jpg |caption = The museum in 2011 |image_size = 300px |map_type = |coordinates = {{Coord|22|54|21|S|43|13|34|W|display=inline,title}} |established = {{Start date|1818|06|06|df=y}} |location = [[Quinta da Boa Vista]] in [[Rio de Janeiro]], [[Brazil]] |type = [[Natural history]], [[ethnology]] and [[archaeology]] |collection = approx. 20 million objects (before 2018 fire),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.museus.gov.br/wp-content/uploads/2011/11/museus_em_numeros_volume1.pdf|title=Museus em Números, Vol. 1|work=Instituto Brasileiro de Museus – IBRAM|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151029034028/http://www.museus.gov.br/wp-content/uploads/2011/11/museus_em_numeros_volume1.pdf|archivedate=29 October 2015|page=73}}</ref> 1.5 million objects placed in other buildings (after 02.09.2018 fire) |visitors = approx. 150,000 (2017)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/200_anos/doc/200_anos_do_Museu_Nacional.pdf|title=200 Anos do Museu Nacional|publisher=Associação Amigos do Museu Nacional|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170708083018/http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/200_anos/doc/200_anos_do_Museu_Nacional.pdf|archivedate=8 July 2017|page=8}}</ref> |director = [[Alexander Kellner|Alexander Wilhelm Armin Kellner]] |curator = |founder = [[João VI of Portugal|King João VI of Portugal, Brazil and the Algarves]] |owner = Federal University of Rio De Janeiro or UFRJ |website = [http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br www.museunacional.ufrj.br] }} The '''National Museum''' ({{lang-pt|Museu Nacional}}) is Brazil's oldest scientific institution,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.oeco.org.br/blogs/salada-verde/video-o-museu-nacional-vive-por-alexander-kellner/|title=Museum lives|publisher=Eco & Youtube|language=pt|access-date=8 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/dir/omuseu/omuseu.html|title=O Museu Nacional é uma instituição autônoma, integra...|publisher=Museu Nacional Ufrj|language=pt|access-date=7 October 2018}}</ref> which was installed in the [[Paço de São Cristóvão]] (Saint Christopher's [[Palace]]), inside the [[Quinta da Boa Vista]], in the city of [[Rio de Janeiro]]. The main building was originally the residence of the [[House of Braganza|Portuguese Royal Family]] between 1808 and 1821 and was later used to house the [[Brazilian Imperial Family]] between 1822 and 1889. After the monarchy was deposed, it hosted the Republican Constituent Assembly from 1889 to 1891 before being assigned to the use of the museum in 1892. The building was listed as Brazilian National Heritage in 1938.<ref name="Museus do Rio - MNRJ">{{Cite document| title=Museu Nacional – UFRJ| publisher=Museus do Rio| year=| url=http://www.museusdorio.com.br/joomla/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&id=12:museu-nacional| accessdate=15 February 2017| postscript=<!--None-->| language=pt| journal=| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170215122231/http://www.museusdorio.com.br/joomla/index.php?option=com_k2&view=item&id=12:museu-nacional| archive-date=15 February 2017| dead-url=no| df=}}</ref>
Founded by [[João VI of Portugal|King João VI of Portugal, Brazil and the Algarves]] on 6 June 1818, under the name of "Royal Museum", the institution was initially housed at the [[Campo de Santana (park)|Campo de Santana park]], where it exhibited the collections incorporated from the former House of Natural History, popularly known as ''Casa dos Pássaros'' ("House of the Birds"), created in 1784 by the Viceroy of Brazil, {{ill|Luís de Vasconcelos e Sousa, 4th Count of Figueiró|pt|Luís de Vasconcelos e Sousa, 4.º Conde de Figueiró}}, as well as collections of [[mineralogy]] and zoology. The museum foundation was intended to address the interests of promoting the [[socioeconomic development]] of the country by the diffusion of education, culture, and science. In the 19th century, the institution was already established as the most important South American museum of its type. In 1946, it was incorporated into the [[Federal University of Rio de Janeiro]].<ref name="Larousse 4132">{{cite book|last= |first=|authorlink=|title=Grande Enciclopédia Larousse Cultural|year=1998|publisher=Banco Safra|location=Santana de Parnaíba|pages=4132|ISBN=}}</ref><ref name="Museus do Rio - MNRJ"/><ref name="MN UFRJ O Museu">{{Cite document| title=O Museu| publisher=Museu Nacional - UFRJ| year=| url=http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/dir/omuseu/omuseu.html| accessdate=15 February 2017| postscript=<!--None-->| language=pt| journal=| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170215124011/http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/dir/omuseu/omuseu.html| archive-date=15 February 2017| dead-url=no| df=}}</ref>
The National Museum held a vast collection with more than 20 million objects, one of the largest collections of [[natural history]] and [[anthropology|anthropological]] artifacts in the world, encompassing some of the most important material records regarding [[natural science]] and anthropology in Brazil, as well as numerous items that came from other regions of the world and were produced by several cultures and ancient civilizations. Formed along more than two centuries through expeditions, excavations, acquisitions, donations and exchanges, the collection was subdivided into seven main nuclei: [[geology]], [[paleontology]], [[botany]], [[zoology]], [[biological anthropology]], [[archaeology]], and [[ethnology]]. The collection was the principal basis for the research conducted by the academic departments of the museum{{snd}}which are responsible for carrying out activities in all the regions of the Brazilian territory and several places of the world, including the [[Antarctica|Antarctic continent]]. The museum held one of the largest scientific [[library|libraries]] of Brazil, with over 470,000 volumes and 2,400 rare works.<ref name="Museus do Rio - MNRJ"/>
In the area of education, the museum offers [[Academic specialization|specialization]]s, [[Continuing education|extension]] and post-graduation courses in several fields of the knowledge, in addition to hosting temporary and permanent exhibitions and educational activities open to the general public.<ref name="Museus do Rio - MNRJ"/> The museum manages the ''Horto Botânico'' (Botanical Garden), adjacent to the ''Paço de São Cristóvão'', as well as an advanced campus in the city of [[Santa Teresa, Espírito Santo|Santa Teresa]], in [[Espírito Santo]]{{snd}}the Santa Lúcia Biological Station, jointly managed with the Museum of Biology Prof. Mello Leitão. A third site, located in the city of [[Saquarema]], is used as a support and logistics center for field activities. Finally, the museum is also dedicated to editorial production, outstanding in that field the ''[[Archivos do Museu Nacional]]'', the oldest scientific journal of Brazil,<ref>{{Cite document|title=Arquivos do Museu Nacional Vol. 62 N. 3|year=2004|url=http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/publicacoes/wp-content/arquivos/Arqs%2062%20n%203%20Completo.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180904030911/http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/publicacoes/wp-content/arquivos/Arqs%2062%20n%203%20Completo.pdf|archivedate=4 September 2018|journal=|access-date=3 September 2018|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> continuously published since 1876.<ref name="Larousse 4132"/><ref name="Revista Arquivos do MN 1">{{Cite document | title=A Revista Arquivos e a Biblioteca do Museu Nacional | publisher=Revista do Arquivo Nacional| year=| url=http://revista.arquivonacional.gov.br/index.php/revistaacervo/article/view/492/491| accessdate=15 February 2017 | postscript= <!--None-->|language=pt}}{{dead link|date=September 2018}}</ref>
The palace, which housed a large part of the collection, was destroyed in a fire on the night of 2 September 2018.<ref name=reuters20180902/><ref name=bbc20180902/><ref name=noticiasBrazil20180902/> The building had been called a "firetrap" by critics, who argued the fire was predictable and could have been prevented.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/leaders/2018/09/08/lessons-from-the-destruction-of-the-national-museum-of-brazil|title=Lessons from the destruction of the National Museum of Brazil|work=The Economist|access-date=2018-09-13|language=en}}</ref> In the wake of the fire, the [[ruin]]ed edifice is undergoing [[Reconstruction (architecture)|reconstruction]] efforts, with a metallic roof covering 5,000 m² [[area]] including [[debris]], being treated as an "[[archaeological site]]".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://noticias.uol.com.br/cotidiano/ultimas-noticias/2018/09/14/museu-nacional-e-liberado-para-acoes-de-prevencao-e-estabilizacao.htm|title=Museu Nacional é liberado para ações de prevenção e estabilização|date=14 September 2018|website=UOL|language=pt|access-date=15 September 2018}}</ref>
== History == [[File:Quinta da Boa Vista 10.jpg|left|thumb|The former [[Paço de São Cristóvão|Imperial Palace]] that housed the National Museum]]
The National Museum was officially established by [[Majesty|His Majesty]] [[João VI of Portugal|King João VI of Portugal, Brazil and the Algarves]] (1769–1826) in 1818 with the name of ''Royal Museum'', in an initiative to stimulate scientific research in the [[Kingdom of Brazil]], then a constituent part of the [[United Kingdom of Portugal, Brazil and the Algarves]]. Initially the Museum sheltered [[botanical]] and [[animal]] [[Biological specimen|specimen]]s, especially [[bird]]s, what caused the old building where it was located in center of Rio de Janeiro, to be known by the population as the "House of the Birds".
After that, with the marriage of King João VI's eldest son and Brazil's first Emperor, [[Pedro I of Brazil|Dom Pedro I]] (1798–1834), with [[Her Imperial and Royal Highness|H.I. & R.H.]] [[Archduchess]] [[Maria Leopoldina of Austria]] (1797-1826), the Museum started to attract the greatest [[Europe]]an [[natural history|naturalist]]s of the 19th century, such as [[Maximilian zu Wied-Neuwied]] (1782–1867), [[Johann Baptist von Spix]] (1781–1826) and [[Carl Friedrich Philipp von Martius]] (1794–1868). Other European researchers who explored the country, such as [[Augustin Saint-Hilaire]] (1799–1853) and the [[Baron von Langsdorff]] (1774–1891), contributed to the collections of the Royal Museum.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vmrviVAKB4UC&pg=PA53&lpg=PA53&dq=Langsdorff+museu+nacional+brazil&source=bl&ots=OoDhjOJm05&sig=GQYQyaNVKOdO0FWVsqdyuAPkEGc&hl=hu&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjHp9n-_ajdAhWIJlAKHRyWAiMQ6AEwBXoECAkQAQ#v=onepage&q=Langsdorff%20museu%20nacional%20brazil&f=false|title=Space for Science: The Development of the Scientific Community in Brazil|author=Simon Schwartzman|publisher=Penn State Press|page=53|accessdate=2018-09-07|language=english}}</ref>
By the end of the 19th century, reflecting the personal preferences of [[His Imperial Majesty]] [[Emperor of Brazil|Emperor]] [[Pedro II of Brazil|Pedro II]] (1825–1891), the National Museum started to invest in the areas of the [[anthropology]], [[paleontology]] and [[archaeology]]. The Emperor himself, who was an avid amateur [[scientist]] and enthusiastic supporter of all branches of science, contributed with several of the collections of the [[art of Ancient Egypt]], [[botany|botanical]] [[fossil]]s, etc., which he acquired during many of his trips abroad. In this way, the National Museum was modernized and became the most important museum of Natural History and Human Sciences of [[South America]].{{Citation needed|date=October 2013}} [[Edmund Roberts (diplomat)|Edmund Roberts]] visited the museum in 1832, noting that the museum only had three open rooms at that time, and that the closed rooms were "sadly plundered of its contents by Don Pedro."<ref name=Roberts>{{cite book|last=Roberts|first=Edmund|title=Embassy to the Eastern Courts of Cochin-China, Siam, and Muscat|year=1837|publisher=Harper & Brothers|location=New York|page=25|url=http://www.wdl.org/en/item/7317/view/1/25/|access-date=10 October 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150610213410/http://www.wdl.org/en/item/7317/view/1/25/|archive-date=10 June 2015|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>
[[File:MuseuNacional1870.jpg|thumb|303px|right|The National Museum at its first location in Campo de Sant'Anna, today's Praça da República, ca. 1870]] [[File:1905 Sala Spix Museu Nacional do Rio de Janeiro.png|thumb|left|Sala Spix, {{circa|1905}}]]
D. Pedro II was well aware of the shortage of true scientists and naturalists in Brazil. He fixed this problem by inviting foreign scientists to come to work at the Museum. The first to come was [[Ludwig Riedel]] (1761–1861), a German botanist who had participated in Baron von Langsdorff's famed expedition to [[Mato Grosso]] from 1826 to 1828. Other scientists to come were: German chemist [[Theodor Peckolt]] and American geologist and paleontologist [[Charles Frederick Hartt]] (1840–1878). In the following years the Museum gradually became known so it continued to attract several foreign scientists who wished to achieve scientific stature with their work in Brazil, such as [[Fritz Müller]] (1821–1897), [[Hermann von Ihering]] (1850–1930), [[Carl August Wilhelm Schwacke]] (1848–1894), [[Orville Adalbert Derby]] (1851–1915), [[Émil August Goeldi]] (1859–1917), [[Louis Couty]] (1854–1884) and others, all fired by museum director [[Ladislau Netto]] when the Emperor was deposed.
The Emperor was still a very popular figure when he was deposed by a military coup in 1889, so the republicans tried to erase the symbols of the Empire. One of these symbols, the [[Paço de São Cristóvão]], the official residence of the emperors in the [[Quinta da Boa Vista]], became vacant; therefore, in 1892, the National Museum, with all its collections, valuables and researchers, was transferred to this palace, where it stays until today.
In 1946, the Museum’s management was passed to the [[University of Brazil]], currently the [[Federal University of Rio de Janeiro]]. The researchers and their offices and laboratories occupy a good part of the Palace and other buildings erected at Botanical Gardens (Horto Florestal), in the Quinta da Boa Vista park. There, one can find one of the largest scientific libraries of Rio. Currently, the National Museum offers graduate courses in the following areas: [[Anthropology]] and [[Sociology]], [[Botany]], [[Geology]] and [[Paleontology]], and [[Zoology]].
== Collections == {{see also|Collection of fossils in the National Museum of Brazil|Collection of meteorites in the National Museum of Brazil}} The Museum sheltered one of the largest exhibits of the Americas, prior the fire, consisting of animals, [[insects]], [[mineral]]s, [[indigenous peoples|aboriginal]] collections of utensils, Egyptian [[mummy|mummies]] and South American archaeological artifacts, [[meteorite]]s, fossils and many other findings.
[[File:Bendegó meteorite, front, National Museum, Rio de Janeiro.jpg|thumb|[[Bendegó meteorite]], which survived the fire]]
One of the meteorites that was on display is the [[Bendegó meteorite]], which weighs over {{convert|5000|kg|lb}} and was discovered in 1784.<ref name="Sears">{{cite journal|last1=Sears|first1=P M|title=Recovery of the Bendego Meteorite|journal=Meteoritics|date=1963|volume=2|issue=1|pages=22–23|url=http://adsabs.harvard.edu/full/1963Metic...2...22S|accessdate=27 December 2017}}</ref>
=== Archaeology === The collection of archaeology of the National Museum comprised more than 100,000 objects, covering distinct several civilizations that lived in the Americas, Europe, Africa, and Middle East, since the [[Paleolithic|Paleolithic Age]] until the 19th century. The collection is subdivided into four main segments: [[Ancient Egypt]], [[History of the Mediterranean region|Mediterranean cultures]], [[Pre-Columbian era|Pre-Columbian]] archaeology, and Pre-Columbian Brazil{{snd}} last nucleus, systematically gathered since 1867, is the largest segment of the archaeological collection, as well as the most important collection of its typology in the world, covering the history of [[Pedro Álvares Cabral|Pre-Cabraline]] Brazil in a very comprehensive manner and sheltering some of the most important material records related to Brazilian archaeology. It was, therefore, a collection of considerable scientific value, and object of several works of basic research, theses, dissertations, and monographs.<ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 45">{{cite book|last= |first=|authorlink=|title=O Museu Nacional|year=2007|publisher=Banco Safra|location=São Paulo|page=45|ISBN=}}</ref><ref name="MNRJ Arqueologia Dep">{{Cite document| title=Departamento de Antropologia| publisher=Museu Nacional/UFRJ| year=| url=http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/dir/pesquisa/antropologia| accessdate=13 February 2017| postscript=<!--None-->| language=pt| journal=| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170214102631/http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/dir/pesquisa/antropologia| archive-date=14 February 2017| dead-url=no| df=}}</ref>
==== Ancient Egypt ==== {{see also|Collection of mummies in the National Museum of Brazil|Collection of funerary steles in the National Museum of Brazil}}
[[Image:B 1431.jpg|thumb|upright=0.9|[[Sarcophagus]] and [[mummy]] of [[Sha-Amun-en-su]]. Third Intermediate Period, XXIII Dynasty, {{circa|750 BC}}.]] With more than 700 items, the collection of [[Egyptology|Egyptian archaeology]] of the National Museum was one of the largest of Latin America and one of the oldest in the Americas. Most part of the objects entered the museum collection in 1826, when the tradesman Nicolau Fiengo brought from [[Marseille]] an assemblage of Egyptian antiquities that belonged to the famous Italian explorer [[Giovanni Battista Belzoni]], who had been in charge of excavating the [[Theban Necropolis]] (modern-day [[Luxor]]) and the [[Karnak|Temple of Karnak]].<ref name="Guia MN-UFRJ Egito 1">{{Cite document| title=Guia de Exposições do Museu Nacional – Egito Antigo (I)| publisher=Museu Nacional/UFRJ| year=| url=http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/guiaMN/Guia/paginas/4/princ9.htm| accessdate=9 February 2017| postscript=<!--None-->| language=pt| journal=| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170315063145/http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/guiaMN/Guia/paginas/4/princ9.htm| archive-date=15 March 2017| dead-url=no| df=}}</ref>
This collection had [[Argentina]] as initial destination, and had probably been ordered by the president of that country, [[Bernardino Rivadavia]], creator of the [[University of Buenos Aires]] and a noted enthusiast of museums. However, a naval blockade at the [[Río de la Plata|La Plata River]] would impede Fiengo of completing his journey, forcing him to return from [[Montevideo]] to Rio de Janeiro, where the pieces were offered at an auction. Emperor [[Pedro I of Brazil|Pedro I]] bought the entire collection for five million ''[[Brazilian real (old)|réis]]'', and subsequently donated it to the National Museum. It has been suggested that the action of Pedro I would have been influenced by [[José Bonifácio de Andrada]], a relevant early member of [[Freemasonry]] in Brazil, perhaps driven by the interest that the organization had for the Egyptian iconography.<ref name="Barkos 2004 31-35">{{cite book|last=Barkos |first=Margaret Marchiori|authorlink=|title=Egiptomania – O Egito no Brasil|year=2004|publisher=Paris Editorial|location=São Paulo|pages=31–35|ISBN=85-72-44261-8}}</ref><ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 222">{{cite book|last= |first=|authorlink=|title=O Museu Nacional|year=2007|publisher=Banco Safra|location=São Paulo|page=222|ISBN=}}</ref> <ref name="Brancaglion 2007">{{cite book|last=Brancaglion Junior |first=Antonio|authorlink=|title=Revelando o Passado: estudos da coleção egípcia do Museu Nacional (in In: Lessa, Fábio de Souza & Bustamente, Regina. "Memoria & festa")|year=2007|publisher=Mauad Editora|location=Rio de Janeiro|pages=75–80|ISBN=}}</ref>
The collection started by Pedro I would be expanded by his son, emperor [[Pedro II of Brazil|Pedro II]], amateur Egyptologist and notable collector of archaeological and ethnographic artifacts. One of the most important additions to the Egyptian collection of the National Museum made by Pedro II is the polychromed wood sarcophagus of the singer of [[Amun]], Sha-Amun-en-su, from the [[Late Period of ancient Egypt|Late Period]], offered to the emperor as a gift during his second trip to Egypt, in 1876, by the [[Khedive]] [[Isma'il Pasha]]. The sarcophagus is distinguished for its rarity, since it is one of few examples that have never been opened, still preserving the [[mummy]] of the singer in its interior.<ref name="Guia MN-UFRJ Egito 1"/> The collection would be enriched through other acquisitions and donations, becoming, at the beginning of the 20th-century, sufficiently relevant to draw the attention of international researchers and egyptologysts, such as [[Alberto Childe]], who served as conservator of the Department of Archaeology of the museum between 1912 and 1938, and was also responsible for publishing the ''Guide of the Collections of Classical Archaeology of the National Museum'', in 1919.<ref name="Barkos 2004 31-35"/><ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 222"/><ref name="Brancaglion 2007"/> [[Image:Múmia feminina 02.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.8|Egyptian mummy ("Princess Kherima"). Roman Period, 1st–3rd centuries AD.]] Besides the forementioned coffin of Sha-Amun-en-su, the museum possesses other three sarcophagi, from the [[Third Intermediate Period of Egypt|Third Intermediate Period]] and the Late Era, belonging to three priests of [[Amun]]: Hori, Pestjef, and Harsiese. The museum also conserves six human mummies (four adults and two children), as well as a number of mummies and sarcophagi of animals (cats, ibises, fishes, and crocodiles). Among the human examples, the highlight is a mummy of a woman from the [[Egypt (Roman province)|Roman Period]], which is considered extremely rare for the preparatory technique used, of which there are only eight similar examples worldwide. Called "princess of the Sun" or "princess Kherima", the mummy has her members and fingers of the hands and feet individually swaddled and is richly adorned, with painted strips.<ref name="Brancaglion 2007"/> "Princess Kherima" is one of the most popular items of the National Museum collection, being even related to accounts of [[Parapsychology|parapsychological experiences]] and collective trances, that supposedly occurred in the 1960s. "Kherima" also inspired the romance ''The Secret of the Mummy'' by Everton Ralph, member of the [[Rosicrucianism|Rosicrucian society]].<ref name="Barkos 2004 31-35"/><ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 41-42">{{cite book|last= |first=|authorlink=|title=O Museu Nacional|year=2007|publisher=Banco Safra|location=São Paulo|pages=41–42|ISBN=}}</ref><ref name="Globo Kherima">{{Cite document| title=Múmia Kherima intriga pesquisadores do Museu Nacional| publisher=O Globo| year=2016| url=http://oglobo.globo.com/sociedade/historia/mumia-kherima-intriga-pesquisadores-do-museu-nacional-10998769| accessdate=9 February 2017| postscript=<!--None-->| language=pt| journal=| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170209230534/http://oglobo.globo.com/sociedade/historia/mumia-kherima-intriga-pesquisadores-do-museu-nacional-10998769| archive-date=9 February 2017| dead-url=no| df=}}</ref>
The collection of votive and funerary [[stele]]s is composed of dozens of pieces dated, in their majority, from the Intermediate Period and the Late Era. The steles of Raia and Haunefer, which are graved with titles of [[Semitic languages|Semitic]] origins present in the [[Bible]] and in the tablets of [[Mari, Syria|Mari]], stand out, as well as an unfinished stele, attributed to the emperor [[Tiberius]], of the Roman Period. The museum also had a vast collection of ''[[Ushabti|shabtis]]'', ''i.e.'' statuettes representing funerary servers, including a group of pieces that belonged to pharaoh [[Seti I]], excavated from his tomb at the [[Valley of the Kings]]. The rare artifacts included a limestone statue of a young woman, dated of the [[New Kingdom of Egypt|New Kingdom]], carrying a conic ointment vessel on the top of her head{{snd}}an iconography that is almost exclusively found among paintings and reliefs. The collection also includes fragments of reliefs, masks, statues of deities in bronze, stone and wood (such as representations of Ptah-Sokar-Osiris), [[canopic jar]]s, alabaster bowls, [[funerary cone]]s, jewels, amulets, etc.<ref name="Barkos 2004 31-35"/><ref name="Brancaglion 2007"/><ref name="Guia MN-UFRJ Egito 2">{{Cite document| title=Guia de Exposições do Museu Nacional – Egito Antigo (II)| publisher=Museu Nacional/UFRJ| year=2016| url=http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/guiaMN/Guia/paginas/4/principal10.htm| accessdate=9 February 2017| postscript=<!--None-->| language=pt| journal=| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160424082027/http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/guiaMN/Guia/paginas/4/principal10.htm| archive-date=24 April 2016| dead-url=no| df=}}</ref>
<center> <gallery> Image:Estela de Raia 01.jpg|Stele of Raia. New Kingdom, XIX Dynasty, {{circa|1300–1200 BC|lk=on}} Image:Esquife de Hori (tampa) 01.jpg|Sarcophagus of [[Hori (High Priest)|Hori]]. Third Intermediate Period, XXI Dynasty, {{circa|1049–1026 BC|lk=no}}. Image:Estatueta egípcia MN-UFRJ 11.jpg|Bronze statuette of Amun. Image:Máscara dourada 01.jpg|Golden mask. Ptolemaic Kingdom, {{circa|304 BC|lk=no}}. Image:Esquife de Harsiese (tampa, interior) 01.jpg|Harsiese Sarcophagus interior Image:Esquife de gato 02.jpg|[[Cat]] Sacophagus Image:Vasos canopos MN-UFRJ 01.jpg|[[Canopic jar]] Image:Leão reclinado 01.jpg|[[Lion]] figure </gallery> </center>
==== Mediterranean cultures ==== {{see also|Collection of Mediterranean antiquities in the National Museum of Brazil}} [[Image:Estatueta Koré 01.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.7|''[[Kore (sculpture)|Kore]]'' statuette, sculpted in marble. Greek civilization, {{circa|5th century BC|lk=on}}.]] The collection of [[classical archaeology]] of the National Museum added up to around 750 pieces and consists mostly of [[Ancient Greece|Greek]], [[Ancient Rome|Roman]], [[Etruscan civilization|Etruscan]], and [[Italiotes|Italiote]] objects, being the largest collection of its kind in Latin America. Most of the pieces previously belonged to the Greco-Roman collection of [[Teresa Cristina of the Two Sicilies|empress Teresa Cristina]], who had been interested in archaeology since her youth. When the empress disembarked in Rio de Janeiro in 1843, right after her [[proxy wedding]] to [[Pedro II of Brazil|emperor Pedro II]], she brought an assemblage of antiquities found during the excavations of [[Herculaneum]] and [[Pompeii]], the Ancient Roman cities destroyed by the eruption of [[Mount Vesuvius]] in 79 AD. Part of this collection had also belonged to [[Caroline Bonaparte|Carolina Murat]], sister of [[Napoleon|Napoleon Bonaparte]] and queen consort of the king of Naples, [[Joachim Murat]].<ref name="MN-UFRJ Arqueologia do Mediterrâneo">{{Cite document| title=Culturas do Mediterrâneo| publisher=Museu Nacional/UFRJ| year=| url=http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/dir/exposicoes/arqueologia/culturas-mediterraneo/index.html| accessdate=9 February 2017| postscript=<!--None-->| language=pt| journal=| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211080941/http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/dir/exposicoes/arqueologia/culturas-mediterraneo/index.html| archive-date=11 February 2017| dead-url=no| df=}}</ref><ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 238">{{cite book|last= |first=|authorlink=|title=O Museu Nacional|year=2007|publisher=Banco Safra|location=São Paulo|pages=238|ISBN=}}</ref><ref name="EBC Coleção TC">{{Cite document| title=Italianos restauram afrescos inéditos da coleção Imperatriz Tereza Cristina| publisher=Agência Brasil| year=| url=http://memoria.ebc.com.br/agenciabrasil/noticia/2004-01-14/italianos-restauram-afrescos-ineditos-da-colecao-imperatriz-tereza-cristina| accessdate=9 February 2017| postscript=<!--None-->| language=pt| journal=| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211080019/http://memoria.ebc.com.br/agenciabrasil/noticia/2004-01-14/italianos-restauram-afrescos-ineditos-da-colecao-imperatriz-tereza-cristina| archive-date=11 February 2017| dead-url=no| df=}}</ref>
In turn, [[Ferdinand II of the Two Sicilies]], brother of empress Teresa Cristina, had ordered the excavations of Herculaneum and Pompeii, initiated in the 18th century, be resumed. The recovered pieces were sent to the [[Naples National Archaeological Museum|Royal Bourbon Museum]] of [[Naples]]. Aiming to increase the number of classical artifacts in Brazil with a view to the future creation of a museum of Greco-Roman archaeology in the country, the empress established formal exchanges with the [[Kingdom of Naples]]. She requested the shipment of Greco-Roman objects to Rio de Janeiro, while sending artifacts of [[Indigenous peoples in Brazil|indigenous origins]] to Italy. The empress also personally financed excavations in [[Veios]], an Etruscan archeological site located fifteen kilometers north of Rome, thus enabling a large part of the objects found there to be brought to Brazil. A greater part of those had been gathered between 1853 and 1859, but Teresa Cristina continued to enrich the collection until the fall of the Brazilian empire in 1889, when the [[Proclamation of the Republic (Brazil)|Republic was proclaimed]] and the empress left the country with all the royal family.<ref name="MN-UFRJ Arqueologia do Mediterrâneo"/><ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 238"/> [[Image:Afresco de Pompéia 02.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.8|Detail of a fresco from the [[Temple of Isis at Pompeii|Temple of Isis]], representing a sea dragon and a dolphin, 1st century AD (Fourth Style).]] Among the highlights of the collection were a set of four [[fresco]]s from Pompeii, made around the 1st century AD. Two of those are decorated with marine motifs, respectively depicting a sea dragon and a seahorse as the central figure surrounded by dolphins, and had adorned the lower walls of the room of the devotees at the [[Temple of Isis (Pompeii)|Temple of Isis]]. The other two frescos are decorated with representations of plants, birds, and landscapes, stylistically close to the paintings of Herculaneum and [[Stabiae]]. The museum also housed a large number of objects from Pompeii portraying the daily life of Ancient Roman citizens: ''[[Fibula (brooch)|fibulae]]'', jewels, mirrors, and other pieces of the Roman female ''toilette'', glass and bronze vessels, phallic amulets, oil lamps molded in terracotta, etc.<ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 41-42"/><ref name="EBC Coleção TC"/><ref name="Guia MN-UFRJ Arqueologia do Mediterrâneo">{{Cite document| title=Guia de Exposições do Museu Nacional – Culturas Mediterrâneas| publisher=Museu Nacional/UFRJ| year=| url=http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/guiaMN/Guia/paginas/3/princ8.htm| accessdate=9 February 2017| postscript=<!--None-->| language=pt| journal=| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180301031214/http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/guiaMN/Guia/paginas/3/princ8.htm| archive-date=1 March 2018| dead-url=no| df=}}</ref>
The collection of Mediterranean [[pottery]] comprised more than dozens of objects and is noted for the diversity of origins, shapes, decorations and utilitarian purposes. Several of the most important styles and schools of classical antiquity are represented, from the [[Corinth]]ian [[Geometric art|geometric style]] of the 7th century BC to the Roman [[terracotta]] [[amphora]]s of the Early Christian era. The museum houses examples of ''[[krater]]s'', ''[[Oenochoe|oenochoai]]'', ''[[kantharos]]'', [[chalice]]s, ''[[kyathos]]'', [[cup]]s, ''[[hydria]]i'', ''[[Lekythos|lekythoi]]'', ''[[Askos (pottery vessel)|askoi]]'', and ''[[lekanides]]''. The groups of Etruscan ''[[Bucchero]]'' pottery (7th–4th centuries BC), Greek [[Black-figure pottery|black-figure vases]] (7th–5th centuries BC), [[Gnathia vases|Gnathian vessels]] (4th century BC), and the vast set of Italian [[Red-figure pottery|red-figure]] vases, with ceramics from [[Apulia]], [[Campania]], [[Lucania]] and [[Magna Graecia]], which also stand out.<ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 41-42"/>
The collection of sculptures comprised a large number of [[Tanagra figurine]]s, small terracotta sculptures of Greek origin that were widely appreciated in the Ancient world, as well as a group of Etruscan bronze statuettes representing warriors and female figures. The collection of military artifacts included entire pieces or fragments of helmets, maces, scabbards, bronze blades, brooches and ''[[phallera]]s''.<ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 41-42"/>
<center> <gallery> Image:Torso nu (Vênus ou Leda) 01.jpg|Venus or Leda. [[Alabaster]] [[sculpture]], Hellenistic. Image:Cálice com cariátides etrusco 02.jpg|Etruscan caryatid [[chalice]], {{circa|620–560 BC|lk=on}} Image:Enócoa coríntia com tampa 01.jpg|Corinthian oinochoe with lid, {{circa|600–575 BC|lk=no}} Image:Cratera em cálice de figuras vermelhas MN 02.jpg|Campanian Red-figure chalice krater, late 4th century BC Image:Arqueologia do Mediterrâneo MN07.jpg|[[Vase]]s Image:Ânfora para vinho MN 01.jpg|[[wine]] [[amphora]] Image:Museu Nacional (Brasil) - pequenas ânforas.jpg||[[Amphora]] Image:Estatuetas femininas em terracota MN 01.jpg|[[Statue]]s Image:Sinos MN 01.jpg|[[bell]]s </gallery> </center>
==== Pre-Columbian archaeology ==== [[Image:Cultura Huari - Figura antropomorfa em cerâmica.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.7|Peruvian [[Wari culture]]. Anthropomorphic ceramic figurine, 500–1200 AD.]] The National Museum housed an important group of about 1,800 artifacts produced by the [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas]] during the [[Pre-Columbian era]], as well as [[Andes|Andean]] [[Mummy|mummies]]. Gathered throughout the 19th century, the collection was based on holdings of the Brazilian royal family, with several objects coming from the private collection of Emperor Pedro II. It was later enlarged through acquisitions, donations, exchanges, and excavations. By the end of the 19th-century, the collection already had considerable prestige, being cited, on the occasion of opening the 1889 Anthropological Exposition, as one of the largest collections of South American archaeology.<ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 41-42"/><ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 19">{{cite book|last= |first=|authorlink=|title=O Museu Nacional|year=2007|publisher=Banco Safra|location=São Paulo|page=19|ISBN=}}</ref><ref name="Projeto Exposição MN/UFRJ">{{Cite document| title=Projeto da Nova Exposição do Museu Nacional/UFRJ| publisher=Museu Nacional/UFRJ| year=| url=http://flanelografo.com.br/impermanencia/biblioteca/Duarte%20et%20al%20(2003).pdf| accessdate=9 February 2017| postscript=<!--None-->| language=pt| journal=| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170214105317/http://flanelografo.com.br/impermanencia/biblioteca/Duarte%20et%20al%20(2003).pdf| archive-date=14 February 2017| dead-url=no| df=}}</ref>
The collection comprised mostly objects related to the [[textile manufacturing]], [[featherwork]], [[pottery|ceramic production]], and [[Stone carving|stonecraft]] of the Andean cultures (groups of [[Peru]], [[Bolivia]], [[Chile]], and [[Argentina]]) and, to a lesser extent, of the [[Amazon rainforest|Amazonian]] natives (including a rare assemblage of artifacts from the area of present-day Venezuela) and [[Mesoamerica]]n cultures (mainly from present-day [[Mexico]] and [[Nicaragua]]). Several aspects of the daily routine, social organization, religiosity, and imagery of the Pre-Columbian civilizations are addressed in the collection, which has items from common daily use (clothing, body ornaments, weapons) to more refined artifacts, imbued with notable artistic sense (measurement and musical instruments, ritual objects, figurative ceramic sculptures and vessels distinguished for their aesthetic features).<ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 19"/><ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 41-42"/> Other aspects of Pre-Columbian life, such as the dynamics of trade, ideological diffusion, and cultural influences among the groups, are also represented in the collection. Items are evaluated in terms of the similarity of decorative patterns and artistic techniques, as well as in the subjects portrayed. Common to nearly all distinct groups are such subjects as plants, nocturnal animals (bats, serpents, owls), and fantastic creatures associated to natural elements and phenomena.<ref name="Visitação Escolar MN/UFRJ">{{Cite document| title=Guia de Visitação Escolar ao Museu Nacional/UFRJ| publisher=Museu Nacional/UFRJ| year=| url=http://www.slideboom.com/presentations/290230/Guia-de-Visita%C3%A7%C3%A3o-da-UFRJ| accessdate=9 February 2017| postscript=<!--None-->| language=pt| journal=| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170214101615/http://www.slideboom.com/presentations/290230/Guia-de-Visita%C3%A7%C3%A3o-da-UFRJ| archive-date=14 February 2017| dead-url=no| df=}}</ref><ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 41-42"/><ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 43">{{cite book|last= |first=|authorlink=|title=O Museu Nacional|year=2007|publisher=Banco Safra|location=São Paulo|page=43|ISBN=}}</ref>
[[Image:Cultura Chancay - Fragmento de tecido com representação de aves MN 01.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1|Peruvian [[Chancay culture]]. Fragment of textile with representation of birds. [[Huaca del Sol]], Late Period, {{circa|1200–1400 AD}}.]] [[Image:Múmia de cabeça - Povo Jivaro 01.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1|[[Shrunken head]], mummified by the Ecuadorian-Peruvian [[Jivaroan peoples]].]]
The best represented groups, in the context of Andean cultures, include: * [[Nazca culture]], which flourished on the southern coast of Peru between the 1st century BC and 800 AD. The National Museum has a large set of fragments of Nazca textiles depicting animals (mainly [[llama]]s), fantastic beings, plants, and geometric patterns;<ref name="Visitação Escolar MN/UFRJ"/> * [[Moche culture|Moche civilization]], which flourished on the northern coast of Peru between the early Christian era and 8th century AD, responsible for building large monuments, temples, pyramids, and ceremonial complexes, represented in the collection by a group of figurative pottery of high artistic and technical quality (zoomorphic, anthropomorphic, and globular vessels) and examples of goldsmithery;<ref name="MNUFRJ Moche">{{Cite document| title=Cultura Moche| publisher=Museu Nacional/UFRJ| year=| url=http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/dir/exposicoes/arqueologia/pre-colombiana/moche.html| accessdate=9 February 2017| postscript=<!--None-->| language=pt| journal=| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170214102019/http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/dir/exposicoes/arqueologia/pre-colombiana/moche.html| archive-date=14 February 2017| dead-url=no| df=}}</ref><ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 290">{{cite book|last= |first=|authorlink=|title=O Museu Nacional|year=2007|publisher=Banco Safra|location=São Paulo|page=290|ISBN=}}</ref> * [[Wari culture]], which inhabited the south-central Andes since the 5th century AD, represented by anthropomorphic ceramic vessels and textile fragments;<ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 290"/> * [[Sican culture|Lambayeque culture]], which arose in the [[Lambayeque Region|homonymous region of Peru]] during the 8th century AD, exemplified in the collection through textiles, pottery and metalwork;<ref name="MNUFRJ Lambayeque">{{Cite document| title=Cultura Lambayeque| publisher=Museu Nacional/UFRJ| year=| url=http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/dir/exposicoes/arqueologia/pre-colombiana/lambayeque.html| accessdate=9 February 2017| postscript=<!--None-->| language=pt| journal=| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170214101946/http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/dir/exposicoes/arqueologia/pre-colombiana/lambayeque.html| archive-date=14 February 2017| dead-url=no| df=}}</ref> * [[Chimú culture]], which flourished on the [[Moche Valley|Valley of the Moche River]] since the 10th century AD, represented by a group of zoomorphic and anthropomorphic pottery (characteristically dark, obtained through the technique of reducing burning, and inspired by stylistic elements of the Moche and Wari cultures), as well as textiles decorated with varying motifs;<ref name="MNUFRJ Chimu">{{Cite document| title=Cultura Chimu| publisher=Museu Nacional/UFRJ| year=| url=http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/dir/exposicoes/arqueologia/pre-colombiana/chimu.html| accessdate=9 February 2017| postscript=<!--None-->| language=pt| journal=| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170214181302/http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/dir/exposicoes/arqueologia/pre-colombiana/chimu.html| archive-date=14 February 2017| dead-url=no| df=}}</ref><ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 296">{{cite book|last= |first=|authorlink=|title=O Museu Nacional|year=2007|publisher=Banco Safra|location=São Paulo|page=296|ISBN=}}</ref> * [[Chancay culture]], which developed between the Intermediate and Late periods (from about 1000 to 1470 AD), on the valleys of the rivers Chancay and Chillon, presented in the collection by a set of anthropomorphic pottery (characteristically dark, decorated with light-colored engobe and brown painting) and sophisticated textiles depicting animals and vegetables{{snd}}namely a large mantle, with three meters of length;<ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 41-42"/><ref name="MNUFRJ Chancay">{{Cite document| title=Cultura Chancay| publisher=Museu Nacional/UFRJ| year=| url=http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/dir/exposicoes/arqueologia/pre-colombiana/chancay.html| accessdate=9 February 2017| postscript=<!--None-->| language=pt| journal=| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170215020734/http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/dir/exposicoes/arqueologia/pre-colombiana/chancay.html| archive-date=15 February 2017| dead-url=no| df=}}</ref> * [[Inca Empire|Inca civilization]], which flourished around the 13th century AD and became the largest empire of the Pre-Columbian Americas in the following century. The National Museum possesses a set of figurative pottery and vessels decorated with geometric patterns ("Incan aryballos"), miniature figures of human beings and llamas, made with alloys of gold, silver, and copper, miniatures of Inca ceremonial clothing, featherwork, ''[[quipu]]s'', mantles, tunics, and several other examples of textiles.<ref name="MNUFRJ Inca">{{Cite document| title=Cultura Inca| publisher=Museu Nacional/UFRJ| year=| url=http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/dir/exposicoes/arqueologia/pre-colombiana/inca.html| accessdate=9 February 2017| postscript=<!--None-->| language=pt| journal=| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170214180300/http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/dir/exposicoes/arqueologia/pre-colombiana/inca.html| archive-date=14 February 2017| dead-url=no| df=}}</ref><ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 304">{{cite book|last= |first=|authorlink=|title=O Museu Nacional|year=2007|publisher=Banco Safra|location=São Paulo|page=304|ISBN=}}</ref>
The collection of Andean mummies of the National Museum allows a glimpse at the funerary practices of the cultures of the region. The mummies of the collection were preserved either naturally (as a result of the favorable geo-climatic conditions of the Andean Mountains) or artificially, in the context of religious and ritualistic practices. Originating from [[San Francisco de Chiu Chiu|Chiu Chiu]], at the [[Atacama Desert]], northern Chile, there is a mummy of a man with an estimated age of 3,400 to 4,700 years, preserved in a seated position, with the head resting on the knees and covered by a wool cap. This was the position which the Atacaman cultures used to sleep, due to the cold climate of the desert. It was also the position in which they were buried, together with their belongings.<ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 308">{{cite book|last= |first=|authorlink=|title=O Museu Nacional|year=2007|publisher=Banco Safra|location=São Paulo|page=308|ISBN=}}</ref> A second mummy in the collection{{snd}}an [[Aymara people|Aymara]] man, found in the surroundings of [[Lake Titicaca]], between Peru and Bolivia{{snd}}is preserved in the same position, but involved in a funerary bundle.<ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 309">{{cite book|last= |first=|authorlink=|title=O Museu Nacional|year=2007|publisher=Banco Safra|location=São Paulo|page=309|ISBN=}}</ref> The collection of mummies also include a boy, donated by the Chilean government, and, illustrating the techniques of artificial mummification of Pre-Columbian cultures, an example of a [[shrunken head]], coming from the [[Jivaroan peoples]] of equatorial Amazon, of ritualistic purposes.<ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 43"/><ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 334">{{cite book|last= |first=|authorlink=|title=O Museu Nacional|year=2007|publisher=Banco Safra|location=São Paulo|page=334|ISBN=}}</ref>

Head-shaped ceramic vessel, {{circa|100 BC–800 AD|lk=no}} File:Civilização Inca - Aríbalo MN 01.jpg|[[Inca Empire|Inca civilization]]. ==== Brazilian archaeology ==== [[Image:Cultura Marajoara - Urna funerária MN 03.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.8|[[Marajoara culture]]. Anthropomorphic funerary urn, 400–1400 AD.]] The collection of Brazilian archaeology of the National Museum brought together a vast set of artifacts produced by the cultures that flourished in the Brazilian territory during the pre-colonial era, with more than 90,000 objects. It was considered the largest collection in its typology worldwide. Gradually assembled since the early 19th century, the collection started being systematically gathered since 1867 and has been continually expanded until the present day, through excavations, acquisitions and donations, also serving as basis for a large number of research projects conducted by the academics of the museum, the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro, and other institutions. It was composed of objects coming from all regions of Brazil, establishing a timeline spanning more than 10,000 years.<ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 43"/><ref name="MNRJ Arqueologia Dep"/><ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 45"/>
From the oldest inhabitants of the Brazilian territory ([[Horticulture|horticulturists]] and [[hunter-gatherer]] groups), the museum preserved several artifacts made of stone ([[flint]], [[quartz]] and other minerals) and bones, such as [[projectile point]]s used for hunting, axe blades of polished stone and other tools used for carving, scraping, cleaving, triturating, and piercing, in addition to artifacts of ceremonial use and adornments. Although objects made of wood, fiber, and resin were also produced, the majority of them didn't stand the test of time and are almost absent in the collection, except for some individual pieces{{snd}}namely a woven straw basket covered by resin, only partially preserved, found in the southern coast of Brazil.<ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 43"/><ref name="Guia Expo MN Arqueologia Brasileira Artefatos Líticos Primeiros Povoadores">{{Cite document| title=Arqueologia Brasileira – Artefatos líticos dos primeiros povoadores| publisher=Guia de Exposições do Museu Nacional| year=| url=http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/guiaMN/Guia/paginas/7/coletaartefatos.htm| accessdate=16 February 2017| postscript=<!--None-->| language=pt| journal=| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150503214622/http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/guiaMN/Guia/paginas/7/coletaartefatos.htm| archive-date=3 May 2015| dead-url=no| df=}}</ref><ref name="Visitação Escolar MN/UFRJ"/><ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 261">{{cite book|last= |first=|authorlink=|title=O Museu Nacional|year=2007|publisher=Banco Safra|location=São Paulo|pages=261|ISBN=}}</ref>
In the segment regarding the [[Sambaqui (culture)|Sambaqui people]], ''i.e.'' the fishing and gathering communities which lived in the south-central coast of Brazil between 8,000 years before present and the early Christian era, the National Museum holds a large number of vestiges originating from deposits constituted of agglomerated lime and organic material{{snd}}the so-called [[Sambaquis]], or [[midden]]s. Two fragments of Sambaquis are preserved in the collection, in addition to a group of human skeletal remains found in these archaeological sites, as well as several cultural testimonies of the Sambaqui people, encompassing utilitarian objects used in routine tasks (vessels, bowls, pestles and mortars carved in stone), ceremonies and rituals (such as votive statuettes). Among the highlights of the Sambaqui collection, there is a large set of [[Zoolite (sculpture)|zoolites]] (stone sculptures of votive use, with representation of animals, such as fish and birds, and human figures).<ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 43"/><ref name="Visitação Escolar MN/UFRJ"/> [[Image:Cultura Santarém - Vaso de gargalo MN 01.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.8|[[Tapajós people|Santarém culture]]. Ceramic vessel ("caryatid" vase), 1000–1400 AD.]] The collection included several examples of funerary urns, rattles, dishes, bowls, clothing, dresses, idols, and amulets, with emphasis being placed on ceramic objects, produced by numerous cultures of precolonial Brazil.<ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 43"/> Best represented groups in the collection include: * [[Marajoara culture]], which flourished on [[Marajó]] island, at the mouth of the [[Amazon River]], between the 5th and the 15th centuries, considered the group that reached the highest level of [[social complexity]] in precolonial Brazil. The museum has a vast assemblage of Marajoara pottery, notable for their heightened artistic and aesthetic sense, as well as for the variety of shapes and refined decoration{{snd}}mostly works of figurative nature (representations of humans and animals), combined with rich geometric patterns (compositions imbued with symmetry, rhythmic repetitions, paired elements, binary oppositions, etc.) and with a predominant usage of the excision technique. Major part of the ceramic pieces are of ceremonial nature, used in funerary contexts, rites of passage, etc. Among the highlights, it's possible to mention the anthropomorphic statuettes (particularly the phallus-shaped female figurines, uniting the male and female principles, a recurring theme of the Marajoara art), large-scale funerary urns, anthropomorphic vases with geometric decoration, ritual thongs, zoomorphic, anthropomorphic and hybrid vessels, etc.<ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 264-275">{{cite book|last= |first=|authorlink=|title=O Museu Nacional|year=2007|publisher=Banco Safra|location=São Paulo|pages=264–275|ISBN=}}</ref> * [[Tapajós people|Santarém culture]] (or Tapajós culture), which inhabited the region of the [[Tapajós|Tapajós River]] in the state of [[Pará]], between the 5th and the 15th centuries, known for their ceramic work of peculiar style and high technical quality, produced with the techniques of modeling, incision, dotted lines, and ''appliqué'', imbued with aesthetic features that suggest the influence of the [[Mesoamerican civilizations]]. Among the highlights of the collection were the anthropomorphic statuettes of naturalist style (characterised by the closed eyes, shaped like coffee beans), the anthropomorphic and zoomorphic vessels, vases for ceremonial use and, above all, the so-called "caryatid vases" – complex ceramic vessels, endowed with bottlenecks, reliefs and pedestals decorated with anthropomorphic and zoomorphic figurines and fantastic beings. The museum also possesses several examples of ''[[Muiraquitã]]s'', ''i.e.'' small statuettes carved in green gems, shaped like animals (mainly frogs) used as adornments or amulets.<ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 264-275"/> [[Image:Cultura Santarém - Vaso antropomorfo representando um homem sentado 01.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.8|[[Tapajós people|Santarém culture]]. Anthropomorphic vase representing a seated man, 1000–1400 AD.]] * [[Konduri culture]], which reached their apex in the 7th century and met their decline in the 15th century, and inhabited the region between the [[Trombetas River|Trombetas]] and [[Nhamundá River|Nhamundá]] rivers, in Pará. Although this culture kept an intense contact with the Santarém culture, their artistic production developed unique features. The Konduri collection is primarily composed of pottery, noted for the techniques of decoration such as incision and dotted lines, the lively polichromy, and the reliefs with anthropomorphic and zoomorphic motifs.<ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 282">{{cite book|last= |first=|authorlink=|title=O Museu Nacional|year=2007|publisher=Banco Safra|location=São Paulo|page=282|ISBN=}}</ref> * [[Trombetas River culture]], which inhabited the lower Amazon, in the state of Pará, near the region of [[Santarém, Pará|Santarém]]. This culture, still largely unknown, was responsible for producing rare artifacts sculpted in polished stone and objects imbued with stylistic elements common to the Mesoamerican cultures. The museum collection preserves lithic artifacts of ceremonial use, as well as anthropomorphic and zoomorphic statuettes (zoolites representing fish and jaguars).<ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 284-285">{{cite book|last= |first=|authorlink=|title=O Museu Nacional|year=2007|publisher=Banco Safra|location=São Paulo|pages=284–285|ISBN=}}</ref> * [[Miracanguera culture]], which flourished on the left bank of the Amazon river, in the region between [[Itacoatiara, Amazonas|Itacoatiara]] and [[Manaus]], between the 9th and the 15th centuries. The museum preserved several examples of ceremonial pottery, mainly anthropomorphic funerary urns characterized by the presence of bulges, necks, and lids, used to store the ashes of the deceased, and other vessels related to funerary rituals. The Miracanguera pottery is distinguished for the presence of ''tabatinga'' layers (clay mixed with organic materials) and the eventual painted decoration of geometric motifs. The plastic composition frequently outlines specific details, such as human figures in a seated position, with the legs represented.<ref name="Guia Expo MN Arqueologia Brasileira Miracanguera">{{Cite document| title=Arqueologia Brasileira – Miracanguera| publisher=Guia de Exposições do Museu Nacional| year=| url=http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/guiaMN/Guia/paginas/7/miracanguera.htm| accessdate=16 February 2017| postscript=<!--None-->| language=pt| journal=| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170228162559/http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/guiaMN/Guia/paginas/7/miracanguera.htm| archive-date=28 February 2017| dead-url=no| df=}}</ref> [[Image:Rio Trombetas - Zoólito em forma de peixe.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.8|[[Trombetas River culture]]. Zoolite in the shape of a fish, w/d.]] * [[Maracá culture]], which lived in the region of [[Amapá]] between the 15th and the 18th centuries, represented in the collection by a group of typical funerary urns depicting male and female figurines in hieratic position, with head-shaped lids, as well as zoomorphic funerary urns depicting quadrupedal animals, originating from indigenous cemeteries located in the outskirts of the [[Maracá River]]. The Maracá pottery was frequently adorned with geometric patterns and polychromed with white, yellow, red, and black pigments. Ornaments in the members and the head of the figures expressed the social identity of the deceased.<ref name="MN Safra 2007 p 286-289">{{cite book|last= |first=|authorlink=|title=O Museu Nacional|year=2007|publisher=Banco Safra|location=São Paulo|pages=286–289|ISBN=}}</ref> * [[Tupi people|Tupi-Guaraní culture]], which inhabited the Brazilian coast when the Portuguese arrived in the 16th century{{snd}}subdivided into the group of the [[Tupinambá people]] (in the [[North Region, Brazil|North]], [[Northeast Region, Brazil|Northeast]], and [[Southeast Region, Brazil|Southeast]] regions of Brazil) and the group of the [[Guaraní people]] (in the [[South Region, Brazil|South region of Brazil]] and parts of [[Argentina]], [[Paraguay]], and [[Uruguay]]). The collection is predominantly composed of ceramics and lithic artifacts of daily use (such as pans, bowls, jars, and dishes) or ritual nature (mainly funerary urns). The Tupi-Guaraní pottery is characterized by its distinct polychromy (with predominance of red, black, and white pigments) and drawings of geometric and sinuous patterns.<ref name="Guia Expo MN Arqueologia Brasileira Cerâmica Tupi-guarani">{{Cite document| title=Arqueologia Brasileira – Cerâmica Tupi-guaran| publisher=Guia de Exposições do Museu Nacional| year=| url=http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/guiaMN/Guia/paginas/7/ceramicatupi.htm| accessdate=16 February 2017| postscript=<!--None-->| language=pt| journal=| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170301013836/http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/guiaMN/Guia/paginas/7/ceramicatupi.htm| archive-date=1 March 2017| dead-url=no| df=}}</ref>
The National Museum held the oldest known examples of indigenous mummies found in the Brazilian territory. The collection consisted of the body of an adult woman of approximately 25 years of age, and two children, one located at her feet, with an estimated age of twelve months, involved in a bundle, and a new-born, also covered by a mantle, positioned behind the head of the woman. This mummified set is composed of individuals that probably belonged to the group of the [[Aimoré people|Botocudos]] (or Aimoré) people, of the [[Macro-Jê languages|Macro-Jê]] branch. They were found at the ''Caverna da Babilônia'', a cavern located in the city of [[Rio Novo, Minas Gerais|Rio Novo]], interior of the state of [[Minas Gerais]], in a farm that belonged to [[Maria José de Santana]], who donated the mummies to emperor Pedro II. As an act of gratitude for this favor, Pedro II awarded Maria José with the title of Baroness of Santana.<ref name="MN Íntimos">{{Cite document| title=Só para os íntimos| publisher=Revista de História| year=| url=http://www.revistadehistoria.com.br/secao/artigos/so-para-os-intimos| accessdate=16 February 2017| postscript=<!--None-->| language=pt}}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
